description: Implement and use computerized provider order entry (CPOE) for medication orders; CPOE must be integrated with EHR system; includes verification of all medication orders entered electronically; drug interaction checks performed at order entry; orders must be transmitted electronically to pharmacy; supports reduction in medication errors and adverse drug events; enables real-time clinical decision support
regulatory_basis: HITECH Section 3001; 45 CFR 170.302; 42 CFR 412.24 (Hospital Quality Reporting); CMS Meaningful Use Definition Rule
applicable_entities: Hospitals; Critical Access Hospitals (CAHs); Eligible Professionals (EPs); Group practices; Healthcare systems; Clinics
measurement_approach: Percentage of medication orders entered through CPOE divided by total medication orders; Medication order submission logs; EHR system audit trails; Pharmacy connectivity verification; Drug interaction check documentation
core_requirement: Yes - Core measure for all providers
clinical_objective: Reduce medication errors; Improve medication safety; Decrease adverse drug events; Enable clinical decision support at point of order
administrative_objective: Establish CPOE governance; Implement staff training; Maintain system documentation; Monitor CPOE utilization; Track error reduction
interoperability_objective: Electronic transmission to pharmacies; Standardized medication order format; Interoperable drug databases; Lab result integration for medication safety
ehr_functionality_required: CPOE module; Drug interaction checking engine; Pharmacy connectivity; Order management system; Clinical decision support integration; Audit logging; Role-based access control
data_elements_involved: Medication names; Dose; Route; Frequency; Indication; Drug allergies; Existing medications; Drug-drug interactions; Lab values relevant to medication; Prescriber identification; Timestamp
implementation_timeline: 2011 Q1-Q2 for initial deployment; 2011 Q3-Q4 for stage 1 compliance; Continuous optimization 2012
documentation_requirements: CPOE implementation plan; Workflow documentation; Staff training records (all clinical staff); System configuration specifications; Drug database update logs; Pharmacy connectivity test results; CPOE performance metrics; Error rate documentation; Clinical outcome data
reporting_requirements: Quarterly meaningful use reporting; Monthly CPOE utilization percentages; Medication error tracking; Drug interaction alert effectiveness; Pharmacy connectivity test results; Staff competency assessments
compliance_verification: CMS/State audit of CPOE functionality; Verification of medication order percentages; Review of workflow processes; Pharmacy system connectivity testing; Clinical staff interviews; Patient chart audits (sample of medication orders); Medication error analysis
audit_procedures: Targeted audits for CPOE implementation; Random chart audits (50-100 charts); System functionality testing; Workflow observation; Staff competency verification; Comparative analysis with peer organizations; Drug interaction alert testing
success_metrics: CPOE adoption rate; Medication order volume via CPOE; Medication error reduction percentage; Adverse drug event reduction; Pharmacy transmission success rate; Staff competency scores; Patient safety improvements; Clinical decision support utilization
failure_consequences: Non-compliance: Loss of incentive payment; Negative payment adjustment beginning 2015; Potential loss of recognition in quality programs; Audit findings; Possible state health department investigation; Loss of meaningful use attestation
related_measures: MU1-Drug Interaction Checking; MU2-CPOE; MU3-CPOE; Promoting Interoperability CPOE measures; Hospital Quality Reporting System measures

description: Issue at least one electronic prescription (e-prescription) for eligible medications; prescriptions transmitted electronically to pharmacy; includes capability to check for drug interactions; supports medication adherence through electronic transmission; reduces prescription errors and illegible prescriptions; enables pharmacy verification; part of meaningful use safety objectives
regulatory_basis: HITECH Section 3001; 45 CFR 170.302; Electronic Prescriptions for Controlled Substances (EPCS) Rule; CMS Meaningful Use Definition Rule; DEA regulation 21 CFR 1300-1312
applicable_entities: Eligible Professionals (EPs); Dentists; Optometrists; Pediatricians; Family medicine practitioners; Internists; Group practices; Healthcare systems; Pharmacies (recipients)
measurement_approach: Percentage of prescriptions issued electronically divided by total prescriptions issued; Prescription transmission logs; Pharmacy delivery confirmation; E-prescription platform documentation; Controlled substance prescription handling
core_requirement: Yes - Core measure for EPs and dentists
clinical_objective: Reduce prescription errors; Improve patient medication safety; Ensure legible prescriptions; Support medication adherence; Enable real-time pharmacy communication; Reduce prescription fraud
administrative_objective: Establish e-prescribing workflow; Implement staff training on e-prescribing; Maintain system configuration; Monitor compliance rates; Document controlled substance procedures; Handle non-e-prescribable medications (controlled substances initially excluded)
interoperability_objective: Standardized prescription format; Pharmacy integration; Controlled substance e-prescription capability; Prescription transmission verification; Pharmacy acknowledgment; Real-time insurance verification; Drug formulary checking
ehr_functionality_required: E-prescribing module; Pharmacy connectivity; Prescription transmission system; Controlled substance management (if applicable); Pharmacy network integration; Digital signature capability (for controlled substances); Audit logging
data_elements_involved: Medication name; Dose; Route; Frequency; Quantity; Refills; Patient demographics; Prescriber information; Pharmacy information; Drug allergy alerts; Insurance information; Timestamp; Authorization codes (for controlled substances)
implementation_timeline: 2011 Q1-Q2 for e-prescribing platform selection; 2011 Q3-Q4 for stage 1 implementation; 2012+ for controlled substance e-prescribing
documentation_requirements: E-prescribing system configuration; Pharmacy partnership agreements; Staff training materials and records; Prescription transmission test results; Workflow documentation; Controlled substance procedure documentation; Compliance tracking methodology
reporting_requirements: Monthly e-prescription submission percentage; Pharmacy transmission success rate; Non-e-prescribable medication tracking; Staff competency assessments; Patient feedback on e-prescriptions; Prescription error rate tracking; Insurance verification success rate
compliance_verification: CMS/State audit of e-prescribing capability; Verification of prescription percentages; Pharmacy connectivity testing; Workflow process review; Staff interviews; Patient chart audits (sample of prescriptions); Controlled substance documentation review; Error analysis
audit_procedures: Targeted audits of high e-prescribing providers; Random chart audits (100+ prescriptions); Pharmacy transmission testing; Workflow observation; Staff competency verification; Non-e-prescribable medication tracking; Controlled substance compliance verification
success_metrics: E-prescription adoption rate; Prescription transmission volume; Prescription error reduction; Patient medication adherence improvement; Pharmacy transmission success rate; Controlled substance compliance; Staff competency; Insurance verification success
failure_consequences: Non-compliance: Loss of incentive eligibility; Negative payment adjustment; Audit findings; Potential state health department investigation; Loss of meaningful use certification; Risk of DEA enforcement (if controlled substances mishandled)
related_measures: MU1-Drug Interaction Checking; MU2-E-Prescribe; MU3-E-Prescribe; Hospital Quality Reporting (for facilities); Promoting Interoperability e-prescribing measures

description: Receive and incorporate lab results into EHR; lab results must be viewable in structured format; must include test name; test result; reference range; unit of measure; date result received; ordering provider information; includes capability to view lab data over time; supports clinical decision-making; facilitates identification of abnormal results
regulatory_basis: HITECH Section 3001; 45 CFR 170.302; CMS Meaningful Use Definition Rule; Laboratory Standards of Care (CLIA regulations); Continuity of Care Document (CCD) Standards
applicable_entities: Hospitals; Critical Access Hospitals; Eligible Professionals; Healthcare systems; Group practices; Laboratories (as data sources); EHR vendors
measurement_approach: Percentage of patients with lab results incorporated into EHR divided by total unique patients seen in reporting period; Lab result receipt logs; EHR documentation showing lab result viewing; Electronic result transmission records; Data integrity verification
threshold_percentage: >=40% of unique patients with lab results (Stage 1); >=50% (Stage 2); >=80% (Stage 3)
clinical_objective: Enable clinical decision-making based on lab data; Facilitate disease monitoring; Improve clinical outcomes; Support diagnosis and treatment decisions; Reduce duplicate testing; Enable comparative analysis of results over time
administrative_objective: Establish laboratory partnerships; Configure EHR to receive lab results; Implement staff training on lab data interpretation; Maintain system documentation; Track lab result incorporation rates; Verify lab data quality; Implement data validation procedures
interoperability_objective: Structured lab data exchange; Standardized lab terminology (LOINC codes); Lab result format standards; Real-time or near-real-time transmission; Exception handling for abnormal results; Audit trails for lab data access
ehr_functionality_required: Lab result receiving module; HL7 v2/FHIR interface for lab data; Lab result viewing and graphing tools; Abnormal result flags; Historical trending functionality; Data validation algorithms; Audit logging
data_elements_involved: Test name (LOINC code); Test result value; Reference range; Unit of measure; Date result received; Lab name and ID; Ordering provider; Patient demographics; Specimen information; Timestamp
implementation_timeline: 2011 Q1-Q2 for lab connectivity planning; 2011 Q3-Q4 for stage 1 lab integration; Ongoing lab partnership expansion
documentation_requirements: Lab integration plan and timelines; Laboratory partnership agreements; EHR configuration specifications; Staff training documentation; HL7/FHIR interface specifications; Lab data quality procedures; Data validation scripts; Error handling documentation
reporting_requirements: Quarterly lab result receipt percentage; Monthly volume of incorporated lab results; Data accuracy and completeness metrics; Lab result viewing frequency; User adoption statistics; Exception handling effectiveness
compliance_verification: CMS/State audit of lab result capability; Verification of patient percentages with lab data; Lab connectivity testing; Review of lab data quality; Staff interviews on lab data utilization; Patient chart audits (100+ charts); Historical trend verification; Data validation testing
audit_procedures: Targeted audits of lab integration effectiveness; Random chart audits with lab result focus; Lab connectivity and data quality testing; Staff workflow observation; Data validation sample testing; Comparative analysis of lab data quality across labs; Exception handling review
success_metrics: Lab result incorporation rate; Lab data accuracy; Lab viewing utilization rate; Clinical decision-making frequency based on lab data; Duplicate test reduction; Efficiency in diagnosis; Patient outcome improvements; Data quality scores
failure_consequences: Non-compliance: Loss of incentive payment; Negative payment adjustment; Lab partnership impact on patient care; Audit findings; Potential state health department investigation; Loss of meaningful use certification; Risk of lab compliance issues
related_measures: MU2-Lab Integration; MU3-Lab Integration; Hospital Quality Reporting lab measures; Promoting Interoperability lab data measures

description: Record vital signs (blood pressure; heart rate; respiratory rate; temperature; oxygen saturation) and body mass index (BMI) for at least one office visit; vital signs and BMI must be documented in structured data fields; includes automated calculation of BMI from height and weight; vital signs must include date and time of measurement; supports identification of abnormal values; enables trending over time; critical for patient safety and chronic disease management
regulatory_basis: HITECH Section 3001; 45 CFR 170.302; CMS Meaningful Use Definition Rule; Clinical quality standards for vital signs documentation
applicable_entities: Hospitals; Critical Access Hospitals; Eligible Professionals; Group practices; Healthcare systems; Clinics; Ambulatory surgery centers
measurement_approach: Percentage of office visits with documented vital signs and BMI divided by total office visits; Vital signs documentation logs; BMI calculation verification; EHR audit trails showing vital signs entry; Staff training documentation
threshold_percentage: >=80% of office visits with vital signs documented (Stage 1); >=90% (Stage 2); >=100% (Stage 3)
clinical_objective: Identify abnormal vital signs promptly; Support chronic disease monitoring; Enable early detection of health issues; Improve patient safety; Support clinical decision-making; Enable population health monitoring
administrative_objective: Implement vital signs workflow in EHR; Train clinical staff on vital signs measurement and documentation; Establish structured data entry fields; Implement automated BMI calculation; Monitor compliance rates; Verify data accuracy; Implement quality checks
interoperability_objective: Structured vital signs data; Automated BMI calculation; Alert generation for abnormal values; Trending functionality; Point-of-care vital signs device integration; Mobile vital signs entry; Real-time alerts to clinicians
ehr_functionality_required: Vital signs documentation module; Point-of-care device interfaces; Automated BMI calculator; Alert system for abnormal ranges; Trending and graphing tools; Mobile/tablet vital signs entry; Data validation rules; Audit logging
data_elements_involved: Systolic blood pressure; Diastolic blood pressure; Heart rate (beats per minute); Respiratory rate (breaths per minute); Body temperature (Celsius/Fahrenheit); Oxygen saturation percentage; Height (inches/cm); Weight (pounds/kg); BMI (calculated); Measurement timestamp; Clinician name
implementation_timeline: 2011 Q1-Q2 for EHR workflow design; 2011 Q3-Q4 for stage 1 documentation; Continuous monitoring
documentation_requirements: Vital signs EHR workflow documentation; Staff training curriculum and records; Structured data entry field specifications; Point-of-care device integration guidelines; BMI calculation algorithm; Alert threshold configuration; Data quality procedures; Compliance monitoring methodology
reporting_requirements: Quarterly vital signs documentation percentage; Monthly volume of visits with vital signs recorded; BMI documentation rate; Abnormal alert effectiveness; Staff competency assessments; Data accuracy verification; Trending functionality utilization
compliance_verification: CMS/State audit of vital signs documentation; Verification of office visit percentages; Review of vital signs completeness and accuracy; Patient chart audits (100+ visits); Point-of-care device testing; Staff competency verification; Alert system testing; BMI calculation accuracy testing
audit_procedures: Targeted audits of providers with low vital signs documentation; Random chart audits with vital signs focus; Data accuracy and completeness testing; Point-of-care device functionality review; Staff workflow observation; Alert system effectiveness assessment; Trending functionality verification
success_metrics: Vital signs documentation rate; BMI documentation rate; Data accuracy percentage; Abnormal alert response rate; Clinical action taken on abnormal values; Staff competency; Patient safety outcomes; Chronic disease control improvements
failure_consequences: Non-compliance: Loss of incentive payment; Potential patient safety impact from missed abnormal values; Audit findings; Negative payment adjustment; Loss of meaningful use certification; Risk of quality score reduction; Patient safety liability
related_measures: MU2-Vitals; MU3-Vitals; Hospital Quality Reporting vital signs measures; Promoting Interoperability vital signs measures; PQRS quality measures

description: Record smoking status for all patients ages 13 and older at each office visit; smoking status must be documented in structured EHR data field; categories include: current smoker; former smoker; never smoker; unknown status; supports identification of smokers for intervention; critical for preventive health; enables population health analyses; supports chronic disease management in smokers; facilitates smoking cessation counseling
regulatory_basis: HITECH Section 3001; 45 CFR 170.302; CMS Meaningful Use Definition Rule; Healthy People 2020 smoking cessation objectives; USPSTF smoking cessation recommendations
applicable_entities: Hospitals; Critical Access Hospitals; Eligible Professionals; Group practices; Healthcare systems; Clinics; Pediatric practices (if serving patients 13+)
measurement_approach: Percentage of patients ages 13 and older with documented smoking status divided by total patients ages 13+ seen in reporting period; Smoking status documentation logs; EHR audit trails; Staff training records
threshold_percentage: >=80% of patients 13+ with smoking status documented (Stage 1); >=90% (Stage 2); >=100% (Stage 3)
clinical_objective: Identify smokers for intervention and counseling; Support smoking cessation programs; Improve chronic disease management; Reduce smoking-related complications; Enable population health monitoring of smoking prevalence; Support preventive health initiatives
administrative_objective: Implement smoking status workflow in EHR; Train clinical staff on smoking status assessment; Create structured data entry fields; Establish patient age verification (13+); Monitor compliance rates; Implement data quality checks
interoperability_objective: Structured smoking status data; Age-appropriate screening; Alert generation for smokers; Documentation of smoking cessation counseling offered; Linkage to smoking cessation resources; Population health analytics capability; Real-time reporting
ehr_functionality_required: Smoking status documentation module; Age verification algorithm; Structured dropdown/checkbox for smoking status categories; Alert system for smokers; Counseling documentation module; Smoking cessation resource links; Trending and analytics tools; Audit logging
data_elements_involved: Smoking status category (current/former/never/unknown); Date status recorded; Age of patient (to verify 13+); Clinician name; Timestamp; Smoking cessation counseling offered (Y/N); Counseling method; Cessation resources provided
implementation_timeline: 2011 Q1-Q2 for EHR workflow setup; 2011 Q3-Q4 for stage 1 implementation; Ongoing monitoring
documentation_requirements: Smoking status workflow documentation; Staff training curriculum and records; Age verification procedure documentation; Structured data field specifications; Alert configuration; Smoking cessation counseling procedures; Data quality processes; Population health analytics setup
reporting_requirements: Quarterly smoking status documentation percentage; Monthly smoking prevalence statistics; Smoking cessation counseling rates; Staff competency assessments; Data accuracy verification; Alert effectiveness tracking
compliance_verification: CMS/State audit of smoking status documentation; Verification of patient percentages; Review of documentation quality; Patient chart audits (100+ charts); Staff competency verification; Smoking cessation counseling tracking; Alert system testing
audit_procedures: Targeted audits of low smoking status documentation; Random chart audits with smoking status focus; Data accuracy testing; Staff workflow observation; Patient age verification review; Smoking cessation counseling documentation review; Trend analysis of smoking prevalence
success_metrics: Smoking status documentation rate; Current smoker identification rate; Smoking cessation counseling effectiveness; Population smoking prevalence tracking; Staff competency; Data accuracy; Preventive health improvements
failure_consequences: Non-compliance: Loss of incentive payment; Missed opportunity for smoking cessation intervention; Audit findings; Negative payment adjustment; Loss of meaningful use certification; Risk of quality score reduction; Public health impact
related_measures: MU2-Smoking Status; MU3-Smoking Status; Hospital Quality Reporting preventive measures; Promoting Interoperability preventive health measures; PQRS preventive care measures

description: Maintain an active medication list for all patients; medication list must include medication name; dose; route; frequency; documented date; indication; allergy interactions; medication list must be updated at each visit; includes OTC medications when known; supports medication safety; prevents adverse drug interactions; enables pharmacist review; critical for patient safety and care coordination
regulatory_basis: HITECH Section 3001; 45 CFR 170.302; CMS Meaningful Use Definition Rule; Patient Safety Standards; Medication Safety Best Practices
applicable_entities: Hospitals; Critical Access Hospitals; Eligible Professionals; Group practices; Healthcare systems; Clinics; Pharmacies (collaborating entities)
measurement_approach: Percentage of office visits during reporting period where active medication list was documented divided by total office visits; Medication list documentation logs; EHR audit trails; Medication list completeness checks; Update frequency tracking
threshold_percentage: >=80% of office visits with active medication list documentation (Stage 1); >=90% (Stage 2); >=100% (Stage 3)
clinical_objective: Prevent medication errors; Enable detection of adverse drug interactions; Support medication safety; Facilitate care coordination; Enable pharmacist medication review; Improve patient compliance; Support chronic disease management; Enable emergency medication information access
administrative_objective: Implement medication list workflow in EHR; Train clinical staff on medication list maintenance; Establish update procedures at each visit; Implement OTC medication query process; Monitor list completeness; Verify accuracy of medication data; Implement reconciliation procedures
interoperability_objective: Structured medication list with all required elements; Update at each visit; OTC medication inclusion; Medication-allergy cross-checking; Interaction alerts; Patient-provided medication lists accepted; Third-party medication list integration; Medication reconciliation capability; Real-time updates
ehr_functionality_required: Medication list module; Medication database with drug information; Interaction checking engine; Structured medication entry fields; Allergy cross-reference; OTC medication search; Medication reconciliation tools; Alert system; Audit logging
data_elements_involved: Medication name (generic/brand); Dose (amount and unit); Route (oral/IV/etc); Frequency (timing); Indication (reason for medication); Start date; Status (active/discontinued); Side effects/allergies; Prescriber information; Pharmacy name; Last update timestamp
implementation_timeline: 2011 Q1-Q2 for medication list workflow design; 2011 Q3-Q4 for stage 1 documentation; Ongoing updates at each visit
documentation_requirements: Medication list workflow documentation; Staff training curriculum and records; Medication database integration; OTC medication process documentation; Medication reconciliation procedures; Allergy cross-check procedures; Data quality standards; Accuracy verification methodology
reporting_requirements: Quarterly medication list completeness percentage; Monthly documentation frequency; OTC medication inclusion rate; Medication reconciliation frequency; Staff competency assessments; Data accuracy verification; Allergy/interaction detection effectiveness
compliance_verification: CMS/State audit of medication list documentation; Verification of visit percentages; Review of list completeness and accuracy; Patient chart audits (100+ visits); Medication reconciliation verification; OTC medication tracking; Allergy cross-check testing; Interaction detection effectiveness
audit_procedures: Targeted audits of medication list completeness; Random chart audits with medication focus; Data accuracy and completeness testing; OTC medication inclusion verification; Staff competency assessment; Medication reconciliation process review; Allergy/interaction alert testing
success_metrics: Medication list documentation rate; List completeness percentage; Medication accuracy; OTC medication inclusion; Allergy cross-check effectiveness; Medication reconciliation frequency; Staff competency; Patient safety outcomes; Medication error reduction
failure_consequences: Non-compliance: Loss of incentive payment; Increased medication error risk; Patient safety concerns; Audit findings; Negative payment adjustment; Loss of meaningful use certification; Potential patient harm from adverse interactions
related_measures: MU2-Medication List; MU3-Medication List; Hospital Quality Reporting patient safety measures; Promoting Interoperability medication measures

description: Maintain an active allergy list for all patients; allergy list must include allergy substance; reaction; severity; onset date; documented status; must be reviewed and updated at each visit; includes medication allergies; food allergies; environmental allergies; contact allergies; no known allergies (NKDA) must be explicitly documented; critical for patient safety; prevents adverse reactions; supports medication safety; enables emergency care coordination
regulatory_basis: HITECH Section 3001; 45 CFR 170.302; CMS Meaningful Use Definition Rule; Patient Safety and Quality Standards; Medication Safety Best Practices
applicable_entities: Hospitals; Critical Access Hospitals; Eligible Professionals; Group practices; Healthcare systems; Clinics; Emergency departments; Specialty practices
measurement_approach: Percentage of office visits during reporting period where active allergy list was reviewed and updated divided by total office visits; Allergy list documentation logs; EHR audit trails; NKDA documentation; Allergy severity tracking
threshold_percentage: >=80% of office visits with active allergy list review and update (Stage 1); >=90% (Stage 2); >=100% (Stage 3)
clinical_objective: Prevent adverse allergy reactions; Enable medication safety (reduce allergy-related medication errors); Support emergency care by providing allergy information; Facilitate specialist consultation with allergy awareness; Improve care coordination; Enable population-level allergy data analysis; Support quality improvement initiatives
administrative_objective: Implement allergy list workflow in EHR; Train clinical staff on allergy assessment; Establish review and update procedures at each visit; Implement NKDA documentation; Verify allergy information accuracy; Monitor list completeness; Set up allergy alerts for medications
interoperability_objective: Structured allergy list with substance name; Reaction type; Severity level (mild/moderate/severe); Onset date; Status (active/resolved/historical); NKDA explicitly documented when applicable; Cross-check with medications at order entry; Alert generation for allergy-medication interactions; Regular updates at each visit
ehr_functionality_required: Allergy list module; Allergy database with reaction information; Severity classification system; NKDA documentation field; Medication-allergy interaction checker; Alert system for contraindicated medications; Historical allergy tracking; Cross-reference with pharmacy data; Audit logging
data_elements_involved: Allergy substance name; Reaction type (rash/anaphylaxis/etc); Severity (mild/moderate/severe); Onset date; Current status; Documentation date; Clinician name; NKDA indicator if applicable; Related medications to avoid
implementation_timeline: 2011 Q1-Q2 for allergy list workflow design; 2011 Q3-Q4 for stage 1 documentation; Ongoing updates at each visit
documentation_requirements: Allergy list workflow documentation; Staff training curriculum and records; Allergy database integration; NKDA documentation procedure; Medication-allergy interaction procedure; Alert configuration; Data quality standards; Accuracy verification methodology
reporting_requirements: Quarterly allergy list completeness percentage; Monthly documentation frequency; NKDA documentation rate; Medication-allergy interaction alerts (count/effectiveness); Staff competency assessments; Data accuracy verification; Alert response effectiveness
compliance_verification: CMS/State audit of allergy list documentation; Verification of visit percentages; Review of list completeness and accuracy; NKDA documentation verification; Patient chart audits (100+ visits); Medication-allergy interaction testing; Alert system functionality review
audit_procedures: Targeted audits of allergy list documentation; Random chart audits with allergy focus; Data accuracy and completeness testing; NKDA documentation verification; Staff competency assessment; Medication-allergy interaction alert testing; Alert response documentation review
success_metrics: Allergy list documentation rate; List completeness percentage; NKDA documentation rate; Medication-allergy interaction alert effectiveness; Staff competency; Patient safety outcomes; Adverse reaction prevention; Emergency care readiness
failure_consequences: Non-compliance: Loss of incentive payment; Increased risk of adverse allergy reactions; Patient safety concerns; Potential anaphylaxis risk with medications; Audit findings; Negative payment adjustment; Loss of meaningful use certification; Potential patient harm and liability
related_measures: MU2-Allergy List; MU3-Allergy List; Hospital Quality Reporting patient safety measures; Promoting Interoperability patient safety measures; Joint Commission patient safety standards

description: Expand CPOE implementation beyond medications to include all orders: lab orders; diagnostic imaging orders; procedure orders; referral orders; all orders must include clinical justification; orders must be reviewed with clinical decision support before execution; advanced decision support must provide alerts for patient-specific contraindications; must show efficacy in reducing order errors and improving care quality
regulatory_basis: HITECH Section 3001; 45 CFR 170.302; CMS Meaningful Use Stage 2 Final Rule; Hospital Quality Reporting systems; Clinical decision support standards
applicable_entities: Hospitals; Critical Access Hospitals; Healthcare systems; Group practices with lab and imaging capabilities; Ambulatory surgery centers
measurement_approach: Percentage of all orders (medication + lab + imaging + procedure + referral) entered through CPOE; Order entry logs; System audit trails; Decision support logs; Clinical justification documentation
threshold_percentage: >=60% of all orders (Stage 2); >=80% (Stage 3); Expansion beyond Stage 1 medication orders
optional_requirement: No - continuation and expansion of Stage 1
clinical_objective: Reduce clinical errors across all order types; Improve clinical decision-making through advanced CDS; Support complex care coordination; Enable real-time verification of order appropriateness; Improve patient safety across all care domains
administrative_objective: Expand CPOE governance to include all order types; Implement advanced decision support rules; Train clinical staff on expanded CPOE; Monitor utilization across all order categories; Establish feedback mechanisms; Continuously refine decision support
interoperability_objective: Expanded order types (all clinical orders); Advanced clinical decision support rules; Patient-specific CDS alerts; Evidence-based order criteria; Real-time contraindication checking; Clinical justification fields; Multi-stage review process; Integration with ancillary systems
ehr_functionality_required: Expanded CPOE module; Lab order interface; Imaging order interface; Procedure order interface; Referral order interface; Advanced CDS rule engine; Decision support alert system; Justification documentation module; Multi-level approval workflow; Audit logging
data_elements_involved: Order type; Order description; Clinical indication; Patient demographics; Relevant test/procedure/referral details; Clinical decision support recommendation; Clinician response to CDS; Override justification (if applicable); Timestamp; Approving clinician
implementation_timeline: 2013 Q1-Q2 for CPOE expansion planning; 2013 Q3-Q4 for advanced CDS implementation; Staged rollout of order types
documentation_requirements: Expanded CPOE implementation plan; Decision support rule specifications; Staff training curriculum; Lab/Imaging/Procedure system interfaces; CDS alert thresholds; Justification documentation procedures; Data quality standards; Feedback mechanisms
reporting_requirements: Quarterly expanded CPOE utilization percentages; Monthly volume of orders by type; CDS alert frequency and response rates; Order error reduction tracking; Staff competency assessments; System downtime tracking; Override frequency and justification review
compliance_verification: CMS/State audit of expanded CPOE capabilities; Verification of order percentages across all types; CDS rule effectiveness testing; Decision support alert review; Patient chart audits (100+ orders); System interface testing; Staff competency verification; Order error analysis
audit_procedures: Targeted audits of expanded CPOE implementation; Random order audits across all types; CDS alert testing and effectiveness; System integration functionality testing; Staff workflow observation; Override justification review; Error analysis; Comparative effectiveness with peer systems
success_metrics: Expanded CPOE adoption rate; All order type utilization percentage; CDS alert response rate; Order error reduction; Clinical decision quality improvements; Care coordination effectiveness; Patient safety outcomes; System reliability
failure_consequences: Non-compliance: Loss of Stage 2 incentive payment; Competitive disadvantage vs Stage 2 compliant providers; Negative payment adjustment; Audit findings; Loss of meaningful use certification; Reputational impact; Patient safety concerns
related_measures: MU3-Advanced CPOE; Promoting Interoperability CPOE measures; Hospital Quality Reporting ordering measures; PQRS quality measures

description: Implement medication reconciliation process at each care transition (admission; discharge; transfer between care settings); medication list must be compared to current medications; discrepancies must be identified and resolved; reconciliation must include active medication list verification; allergy/interaction cross-checking; documentation of any changes made; supports medication safety across care continuum; prevents adverse events at transitions of care
regulatory_basis: HITECH Section 3001; 45 CFR 170.302; CMS Meaningful Use Stage 2 Final Rule; Joint Commission National Patient Safety Goals; Care Transition Standards
applicable_entities: Hospitals; Critical Access Hospitals; Healthcare systems; Specialty practices; Ambulatory surgical centers; Group practices with transfer agreements
measurement_approach: Percentage of office visits or care transitions during reporting period where medication reconciliation was documented; Reconciliation documentation logs; EHR audit trails; Medication list comparison records; Discrepancy resolution documentation
threshold_percentage: >=50% of office visits/transitions with medication reconciliation (Stage 2); >=90% (Stage 3)
clinical_objective: Identify medication discrepancies at care transitions; Prevent medication errors during transitions; Improve medication safety; Resolve therapy conflicts; Enable seamless care coordination; Improve patient outcomes; Support quality improvement; Reduce re-hospitalizations
administrative_objective: Implement medication reconciliation workflow; Establish procedures at admission/discharge/transfer points; Train clinical staff on reconciliation process; Document discrepancy resolution; Implement EHR functionality for side-by-side comparison; Monitor compliance; Verify accuracy of reconciliation
interoperability_objective: Structured reconciliation process; Patient-provided medication list acceptance; Pharmacy cross-check capability; Previous medication list comparison; Current medication verification; Discrepancy identification and resolution; Documentation of changes; Alert for clinically significant discrepancies
ehr_functionality_required: Medication reconciliation module; Medication list comparison tools; Patient medication list input field; Pharmacy integration for drug verification; Discrepancy identification algorithm; Alert system; Documentation module; Audit trails; Interoperability interface
data_elements_involved: Previous medication list; Current medication list (patient); Clinician-verified medication list; Medications added; Medications discontinued; Medications changed; Discrepancy description; Reason for discrepancy; Resolution action taken; Reconciliation timestamp; Reconciling clinician
implementation_timeline: 2013 Q1-Q2 for reconciliation workflow design; 2013 Q3-Q4 for stage 2 implementation; At each transition point
documentation_requirements: Medication reconciliation workflow documentation; Care transition procedures; Staff training curriculum and records; Pharmacy partnership agreements; EHR functionality specifications; Discrepancy resolution procedures; Quality assurance processes; Documentation templates
reporting_requirements: Quarterly medication reconciliation completion percentage; Monthly volume of reconciliations performed; Discrepancy identification rate; Resolution effectiveness; Staff competency assessments; Care transition quality metrics
compliance_verification: CMS/State audit of reconciliation documentation; Verification of care transition percentages; Review of reconciliation quality and completeness; Patient chart audits (100+ transitions); Pharmacy system cross-checks; Staff competency verification; Discrepancy resolution follow-up
audit_procedures: Targeted audits of care transitions; Random chart audits focused on medication reconciliation; Reconciliation quality and completeness testing; Pharmacy data cross-verification; Staff workflow observation; Discrepancy resolution documentation review
success_metrics: Medication reconciliation completion rate; Discrepancy identification effectiveness; Resolution accuracy; Care transition quality; Patient safety outcomes; Re-hospitalization reduction; Staff competency; Care coordination improvements
failure_consequences: Non-compliance: Loss of Stage 2 incentive payment; Increased medication error risk at care transitions; Patient safety concerns; Audit findings; Negative payment adjustment; Loss of meaningful use certification; Potential adverse events and liability
related_measures: MU3-Medication Reconciliation; Promoting Interoperability medication reconciliation; Hospital Quality Reporting safe transitions measures

description: Participate in state-mandated or national health information exchange (HIE) networks; exchange clinical summary records with other providers; achieve measurable increases in HIE volume and quality; clinical summaries must include problem list; medication list; allergy list; vital signs; lab results; diagnostic findings; must be exchanged in standards-compliant format; supports care coordination across providers; enables continuity of care; improves quality and efficiency
regulatory_basis: HITECH Section 3002; 45 CFR 170.302-304; CMS Meaningful Use Stage 3 Final Rule; 42 CFR 412.24 (Hospital Quality Reporting); NHIN standards; State HIE guidelines
applicable_entities: Hospitals; Critical Access Hospitals; Healthcare systems; Group practices; Eligible Professionals; Telemedicine providers; Specialists coordinating care
measurement_approach: Percentage of office visits where clinical summary for patient was exchanged with other providers; HIE transaction logs; Clinical summary transmission records; Provider acknowledgment documentation; Exchange volume metrics
threshold_percentage: >=50% of office visits with clinical summary exchange (Stage 3); Increasing trend in HIE volume and quality
clinical_objective: Enable seamless care coordination; Improve care quality through information sharing; Reduce duplicate testing; Facilitate specialist consultation; Support care transitions; Improve patient outcomes; Enable population health insights; Reduce healthcare costs through efficiency
administrative_objective: Participate in state HIE network selection; Establish HIE partnerships; Configure EHR for HIE connectivity; Train staff on HIE processes; Monitor exchange volume and quality; Establish data governance for shared information; Implement security and privacy controls
interoperability_objective: Certified HIE network participation; Standards-compliant data exchange (FHIR/HL7 v2/CDA); Secure transmission (encryption); Clinical summary with required elements; Provider directory integration; Query and retrieve capability; Patient consent management; Real-time or near real-time exchange
ehr_functionality_required: HIE connectivity module; FHIR/HL7 interface; Secure transmission protocol; Clinical summary template; Provider directory integration; Query/retrieve tools; Patient consent management; Data validation; Audit logging; Performance monitoring
data_elements_involved: Clinical summary content (problems; medications; allergies; vitals; labs; imaging); Patient demographics; Provider identification; Timestamp; Exchange method; Recipient provider; Patient consent status; Data completeness; Quality indicators
implementation_timeline: 2015 Q1-Q2 for HIE network selection and setup; 2015 Q3-Q4 for stage 3 implementation; Ongoing exchange participation
documentation_requirements: HIE network participation agreement; EHR-HIE connectivity specifications; Staff training curriculum; Data governance policies; Security and privacy procedures; Standards compliance documentation; Quality assurance procedures; Performance monitoring setup
reporting_requirements: Quarterly HIE exchange volume and percentage; Monthly clinical summary transmissions; Exchange quality metrics; Provider directory accuracy; Patient consent rates; Data completeness verification; System uptime and performance; Staff competency assessments
compliance_verification: CMS/State audit of HIE participation; Verification of exchange percentages and volume; Review of clinical summary quality; Data standards compliance verification; Patient chart audits (100+ exchanges); HIE network testing; Security and privacy compliance; Patient consent review
audit_procedures: Targeted audits of HIE implementation; Random exchange audits for quality and completeness; Data standards compliance testing; Provider directory accuracy verification; Security and privacy compliance review; Staff competency assessment; Comparative analysis with peer HIE providers
success_metrics: HIE participation rate; Clinical summary exchange volume; Exchange quality percentage; Data completeness; Provider participation; Patient consent rates; Care coordination improvements; Quality outcomes; Cost reduction indicators
failure_consequences: Non-compliance: Loss of Stage 3 incentive payment; Exclusion from advanced payment models; Competitive disadvantage; Negative payment adjustment; Loss of quality recognition; Reduced ability to coordinate care; Audit findings; Loss of meaningful use certification
related_measures: Promoting Interoperability HIE measures; State HIE participation; Federal NHIN connectivity; Care coordination quality measures

description: Provide patient access to electronic health information through secure API (Application Programming Interface); patients must be able to download; transmit; or access their complete EHR data; includes problem list; medication list; allergy list; vital signs; lab results; imaging results; clinical notes; patients must be able to use third-party applications to access and manage their health data; must comply with FHIR or other open standards; supports patient autonomy and data portability; enables patient-directed care; supports population health research
regulatory_basis: HITECH Section 3002; 45 CFR 170.302-304; CMS Meaningful Use Stage 3 Final Rule; 21st Century Cures Act Section 4001 (Information Blocking); 42 CFR 414.1315 (Promoting Interoperability);ONC Patient Access API Rule
applicable_entities: All Medicare providers participating in Meaningful Use; Hospitals; Healthcare systems; Group practices; Eligible Professionals; Telemedicine providers; Specialty practices
measurement_approach: Percentage of patients with access to their electronic health information through API or secure download; API transaction logs; Patient portal activity logs; Third-party application access logs; Data download records
threshold_percentage: >=80% of patients offered API access (Stage 3); >=90% (Promoting Interoperability)
clinical_objective: Empower patients with access to their health data; Enable patient participation in care; Support chronic disease self-management; Facilitate patient-provider communication; Enable patient-directed research participation; Reduce health disparities through data access; Support health literacy
administrative_objective: Implement patient API functionality; Configure secure authentication; Train staff on API processes; Publicize API availability to patients; Monitor API utilization; Address API issues/errors; Ensure compliance with data security standards
interoperability_objective: FHIR-compliant API; Secure authentication (OAuth 2.0 or equivalent); Encryption for data in transit; Patient authorization controls; Downloadable data format (PDF/CSV/XML); Third-party app integration; Documentation of API availability; Real-time API access; Performance monitoring
ehr_functionality_required: Patient API module; FHIR server; Authentication system (OAuth 2.0); Secure transmission protocol (HTTPS/TLS); Patient portal interface; Data export/download tools; Third-party integration capability; Usage analytics; Security monitoring; Audit logging
data_elements_involved: All EHR data accessible via API: problem list; medication list; allergy list; vital signs; lab results; imaging results; clinical notes; procedures; immunizations; patient contact information; insurance information; Any modifications to API scope; Timestamp; Patient consent status; API access logs
implementation_timeline: 2015 Q1-Q2 for API development and testing; 2015 Q3-Q4 for stage 3 implementation; Ongoing access provision and support
documentation_requirements: Patient API architecture and specifications; FHIR standards compliance documentation; Authentication and security procedures; Patient portal integration design; Staff training curriculum; API availability publicity plan; Third-party integration guidelines; Performance and security monitoring; Error handling procedures
reporting_requirements: Quarterly API availability and performance metrics; Monthly patient API utilization rates; Number of patients accessing via API; Third-party applications used; Data download frequency; API error rates; User satisfaction surveys; Staff competency assessments
compliance_verification: CMS/State audit of API functionality; Verification of API availability and performance; FHIR compliance testing; Security and authentication testing; Patient access verification; Third-party integration review; Patient satisfaction assessment; Data protection verification
audit_procedures: Targeted audits of API implementation; API functionality and performance testing; FHIR standards compliance verification; Security and authentication testing; Patient access and data accuracy verification; Third-party integration review; Performance monitoring; User experience assessment
success_metrics: API adoption rate; Patient access percentage; API utilization frequency; Third-party integration uptake; Patient satisfaction; Data security incidents (should be minimal); System reliability; User engagement; Patient empowerment indicators
failure_consequences: Non-compliance: Loss of Stage 3 incentive payment; Information blocking violation with up to $100
related_measures: 000+ penalties; Exclusion from advanced payment models; Competitive disadvantage; Negative payment adjustment; Loss of quality recognition; Audit findings; Loss of meaningful use certification; Potential OHI OCR investigation
priority_level: Promoting Interoperability API measures; 21st Century Cures Act Patient Access Rule; State API requirements; Federal NHIN connectivity
